body:
I think that, perhaps, you are looking at christianity through a lens of not fully understanding it, or maybe you've run into christians who don't fully understand it themselves.

1. The bible doesn't say you are a piece of shit, it says that we are born into a sin nature that cannot exist before God, but that sin nature can be washed away because, yes, God loves us and Jesus, his son, paid the price that was due from us for that sin - death. However, since God gave us free will we must make a choice to accept that free gift. God acknowledges that there are many people who are kind and good in the world, but those actions don't wash away the infection of sin, only one thing does that and we have to voluntarily take that step. Its like if you were a great, kind and giving person who had cancer. Sure you can keep doing all the good and kind things you want, but that won't cure your cancer, you still need to go to a doctor and get specific treatment for that. If you choose not to do it you can't blame the doctor for it, he was always there, you just didn't want to go.

2. Turning the other cheek isn't blanket statement about being non-violent. The God of the bible is a God of war. Turn the other cheek is speaking to the members of the church and basically telling them not to be quick to anger with one another, but its taken out of context by both christians and non-christians. Kind of like how the whole, "Well Jesus washed the disciples feet so christians need to be servants to everyone" mess gets taken out of context. In context it has to do with how members of the church body treat each other and how no one should feel they are too good for lowly jobs that need to get done. One of the last things Jesus told the disciples before he left them was to buy a sword, and if they didn't have enough money for one, to literally sell their coat to get one. As a christian, there has been no other revelation from God to put that sword down, and until there is one, I keep my sword handy, just in case.

3. I've written a half dozen blog posts on how modern Western christians have zero understanding of the sin called "lust", and that, no, even looking at another mans wife and thinking "Damn, I'd fuck her" doesn't equate to sin. Its a common misconception that has been formed mostly because of Western feminism and weak men. Rest assured, however, that checking out that hot redhead sitting across the restaurant and imagining what she would look like buck naked and tied down to a table does not meet the definition of being "lust".

Overall there are very few "technical points" to christianity, but certain people and groups of people have focused in on and warped certain aspects of it for their own gain. It took me sitting down and reading my bible from cover to cover to truly understand the simplicity of it, and the simplicity of being a christian.

Hope that shed a little light. I'd be more than happy to discuss anything further.
